title: 2D materials may enable electric vehicles to get 500 miles on a single charge | College of Engineering | University of Illinois at Chicago

College of Engineering     Search the site     Toggle Menu      Search                  College of Engineering      College of Engineering   Main Menu    Undergraduate           Admitted Student Information    Admissions    Advising    Career Outcomes    Diversity    Engineering Expo    FAQ    Majors and Minors    Paid Internships    Scholarships    Student Groups    Student Resources    Women in Engineering         Graduate    Departments    Research           Interdisciplinary Research    Labs and Centers         Support UIC           Donate Online    How to Give    Help Students    Empower Faculty    Capital Projects         About           Dean    Faculty    Administration    Staff    Alumni    Advisory Board    Facilities    Summer Camp    News    Contact          Eyebrow menu    Give    Careers    Alumni    UIC menu    UIC.edu    Campus Map       Search                     2D materials may enable electric vehicles to get 500 miles on a single charge    Posted on January 14, 2019            story title   Lithium-air batteries are poised to become the next revolutionary replacement for currently used lithium-ion batteries that power electric vehicles, cell phones and computers.  Lithium-air batteries, which currently are still in the experimental stages of development, can store 10 times more energy than lithium-ion batteries, and they are much lighter. That said, lithium-air batteries could be even more efficient and provide more charge with the incorporation of advanced catalysts made from two-dimensional materials. Catalysts help increase the rate of chemical reactions inside batteries, and depending on the type of material from which the catalyst is made, they can help significantly boost the ability of the battery to hold and provide energy.  Read more at UIC Today .      Modified on June 02, 2019
